data.wave_or_subset: Fourth wave (fielded Nov 2007 – Apr 2008); subset of adults aged 45+ identified as hypertensive
data.sample_size: 4209 hypertensive adults for disease-detection analysis; 1696 previously diagnosed hypertensive adults for disease-management analysis
data.access_details: IFLS is publicly available from RAND Corporation upon free registration
data.notes: Blood pressure measured three times by nurses; first reading dropped, remaining two averaged. Education measured in years of schooling. Time and risk preferences elicited through hypothetical lottery questions; grouped into four-category indices.

method.description: The authors estimate discrete-choice (probit) models to examine how education and elicited time preferences influence: (1) the probability that a hypertensive adult is undiagnosed, and (2) the probability that diagnosed individuals monitor their blood pressure within the past month. Analyses are run on the full sample and separately for respondents reporting good versus poor self-rated general health.
steps: Select adults aged 45+ who participated in IFLS4 and have complete biomarker and survey data.
Classify individuals as hypertensive using averaged systolic ≥140 mm Hg or diastolic ≥90 mm Hg.
Identify ‘under-diagnosed’ respondents: hypertensive but never told by a doctor.
Create self-rated general health variable and split sample into ‘good’ and ‘poor’ health subgroups.

Construct key regressors: years of education, four-level time-preference index, four-level risk-preference index, log per-capita household expenditures, distance to nearest health centre, sex, age and age squared.
Estimate probit models for each outcome (under-diagnosis; recent BP check) on full sample and subsamples; compute marginal effects.
Interpret differential effects of education and impatience across health-status groups.
method.outcome_variable: 1) Under-diagnosis of hypertension (binary); 2) Engagement in good disease management defined as blood-pressure check in past month (binary)
method.independent_variables: Years of education; categorical time-preference index; categorical risk-preference index; log per-capita household expenditures; distance to health centre; female dummy

results.summary: Education and time preferences both influence asymptomatic disease detection, but their effects differ by respondents’ overall health. Among individuals in good self-rated health, impatience increases the likelihood of remaining undiagnosed while education has no effect. Among those in poor health, higher education significantly reduces under-diagnosis whereas time preference becomes irrelevant. Similar patterns emerge for disease management: education improves the probability of regular blood-pressure monitoring for all groups (stronger in poor health), while impatience discourages monitoring only among those in good health. Household resources and proximity to health centres matter mainly for healthier individuals; women are less likely than men to be undiagnosed.

numerical_results.unit: marginal effect per additional year of schooling
marginal effect of higher impatience category
marginal effect per additional year of schooling

metadata.original_paper_title: Education, individual time preferences, and asymptomatic disease detection
